Our first thoughts on a short-seller note published today on BUR are that, after a detailed reply, the company should seek longer-term remedies which we think lie in the areas of communication and governance. We think the concerns raised around liquidity are less robust and learnt no new information in that area or on governance from the note. We look forward to both the initial and longer-term management response.
The short-seller note published this morning focuses on three main areas:
1. how returns are calculated and reported, to which BUR’s accounting is
related
2. liquidity
3. governance structures
We think the first of these is the most important. On the calculation of returns, the short seller lists seven techniques it alleges are used to manipulate returns data.
Each is related to individual investments and we will be interested to see the detailed management responses. Where we would question the short argument at first sight though is on the idea that BUR marks investment values aggressively: we think the evidence of individual disclosed investments points the other way (see note).
In terms of liquidity, the authors look at the size of the invested capital base generating returns to cover costs, while our starting point would be cash. We do not think BUR faces difficulty covering its expenses.
We are cognizant of the corporate governance concerns relating to the relationship between the CEO and the CFO, and the composition of the board. This is already wellknown public information and we have discussed them frequently with investors.

Grouchmonkey Morning
BE11:27am

What next?
We would expect the company’s response to provide further information relating to individual investment return reporting, and to deal with the points in the report in greater detail. This should allow investors to assess the most important parts of the short argument better.
Where BUR can most obviously make changes is, we believe, in governance and communication. We have long said that some form of guidance or quarterly updates could be given and we think these combined could go a long way towards removing uncertainty, particularly given that the company has no scheduled market communications between now and March next year.

Comment: This is a strongly worded statement from Burford and Muddy Waters will have to be pretty certain of its investment case when targeting a company run by lawyers. Unfortunately, Burford’s business model does invite scrutiny (and always has) because of the nature of its assets and the accounting, which requires management judgment to derive the most important numbers in the accounts. However, Burford’s application of the standard has been conservative (only two investments that were ever written down were subsequently reversed; Teinver was held at USD70m compared to a potential payout of USD140m even following adjudication). Liquidity also looks strong, with more than USD400m of cash on hand, compared to annualised operating expenses and finance charges of USD112m, and contingent commitments of USD708m (of which Burford expects less than 50% to be drawn over the next 12 months). Finally, the threat of legal action, while common in such situations, is more potent from a company involved in the legal profession, in our view.

Fielding numerous incoming calls on today’s share price decline of c.11% on no news (vs. FTSE flat) and somewhat reminiscent of the 27th of March, it was clear that the price action has left investors scratching their heads. As we wrote earlier today (see Yesterday's weakness expected to reverse, 7 Aug), we expected the shares to recover from yesterday’s weakness, which was attributed to a tweet from an activist short seller that was later confirmed as not being about NMC Health. We have been on the road over the last couple of weeks, and investor feedback on underlying fundamentals has been positive with pushback centered largely around communication (interest-driven earnings miss and higher capex), pledges (albeit partially alleviated with 6m shares released from the pledge [see Progress on the pledge, 5 Aug] this week) and corporate governance/accounting. Many investors we speak to consider the stock to be very attractive at these levels but await evidence of improved execution with delivery on earnings and FCF. With the short base at c.22% of FF and the stock de-rating to the lowest valuation in over three years, we see fear around the investment case and the disconnect between fundamentals and valuation to be at their highest in some time. Overall, we believe that the company’s last set of results were more encouraging than given credit for (see FY 18 results: Fears allayed, 7 Mar), that accounting concerns are misplaced (see our accounting deep-dive: Healthier than you think, 4 Mar) and that, given highly attractive fundamentals (see: Back from the Kingdom, 26 Jul), this weakness presents an attractive buying opportunity. At c.12x 2020E PE, valuation does not sufficiently a c.27% 17-21E EPS CAGR where growth is amongst the most visible in our sector, in our view. Catalysts include upcoming H1 results (where we expect fundamentals to be brought back into focus) on 22nd of August, further steps to remove Khalifa Bin Butti’s pledge structure, our US October management roadshow and Middle East investor trip (Dec 1st-5th). We continue to like the shares of NMC Health, which is our Top Pick in European MedTech & Services.
